reviewText: Maybe this is a good introduction for viewers who know nothing of Antietam. But, if you are even generally familiar with the battle, this a hugely disappointing account. For starters, it begs for maps showing the course of the battle. There is absolutely no visual or spatial context for what is being portrayed in the battle scenes. The account is completely lacking structure and cohesion that maps would have provided. This would have been very simple and inexpensive to achieve. Yes, there was one overall map but it really was inadequate to explain what was going on. Second, the really cheesy actors portraying the key historical figures, their silly looking makeup and their complete lack of trained voices for the narration just made them comical. Finally, the re-enactors were, as re-enactors usually are, too old and many of them too fat to have any credibility. Ken Burns did a much better job portraying Antietam in "The Civil War" without actors or re-enactors and using professionals to speak the words being quoted and that really is the gold standard. This effort doesn't even come close. Short version: Needs more maps, a more defined story arc, better actors and lose the re-enactors.

reviewText: This is a documentary, not a drama. But the many scenes of reenactments of Antietam by local Civil War buffs drags this down a bit. They don't look realistic. If men were being shot at, they wouldn't look so casual or silly as do the amateurs seen throughout this film. Still, you get a decent recounting of the Civil War's bloodiest battle. The real thing was most surely vastly worse than what you see here.
Title: N/A

reviewText: and this program fits right into that pattern. Based on the fact that Lincoln was ready to announce his Emancipation Proclamation, it was suggested that he wait until a Union victory before announcing it. He agreed, but was not thrilled with the record of the Union forces, nor their leader. The story unfolds and leads us to the South's invasion of the North, and the battle of Antietam which resulted in the "victory" Lincoln needed. The story is done with some very nice still photos of the time, and many scenes of the battle re-enactment. This battle provided more casualties that all wars fought by the U.S. combined, to that date. It is 90 or so minutes well spent if you are a Civil War or history buff.
summary: I am a big fan of all Civil War information

reviewText: With input from the team who completed "Gods and Generals" and "Gettysburg," this is a documentary.  The story itself is compelling, and is predominantly told by modern historians.Using footage from the anniversary re-enactments of the 125th and 140th anniversaries, the commentary provided by the students of this brutal conflict attempt to give context to the bloodiest day in United States history.This is slow-moving at times, but if you endure, you will be appreciative of the context it provides.Spoiler alert -- the last seven minutes give excellent perspective of how many people almost 30,000 lost in a day means.
summary: Well-written portrayal of the most horrific day (people killed) in U.S. history

reviewText: Antietam marked the bloodiest day of all the wars in American Military History. Politically it fulfilled the requirements Pediment Lincoln needed to issue the Emancipation Proclamation. Documented with anniversary reenactments, photos, memoirs, diaries, and interviews, it presents a commentary filled with intriguing detail. Descriptions of prominent personalities in the military, those in the political arena, military tactics, and logistics add dimension.  Antietam lost the potential for international recognition of the Confederate States and it became a political victory for the Republican party in the United States. Technically well presented and narrated. Adds an interesting perspective to the American Civil War.

reviewText: Hopefully, we never see another Civil War in the USA. To think that 23,000 lives were lost in just one day of fighting is unfathomable.This film includes re-enactments, original photos, maps and narration about Antiedam and how it was fought. Seeing the re-enactments, helps to bring this war into reality. The film has an ending that will give you a better understanding as to how many lives were lost. (without giving away how) The ending really, really touched me. I'm very fortunate that my ancestors returned from the Civil War.Anyone who loves US History should take the time to watch this film.
summary: Well documented, the end was especially touching

reviewText: Although a bit dry at the beginning, it is a good overview of the Battle of Antietan.  Some of the perspectives, such as stating that Ambrose Burnside, who has been vilified as perhaps the worst general in the union army, behaved brilliantly during the battle, is exactly the opposite of every other account I have heard about Antietam(the documentary fails to mention that Burnside's casualties were much higher and his advance much slower than need be because he insisted crossing a bridge that was well guarded by confederate troops instead of using an unguarded ford a few miles upstream).  However, I give him points for the description of AP Hill's personal motives for advancing so rapidly and fighting so vigorously(He had suffered personal betrayals at the hands of both McClellan and Burnside, an aspect of the battle of which I was not previously aware.  A good, if not great, documentarAlso, giving Lincoln first billing is perhaps a bit deceptive, as he was, of course, not at Antietam.  However, he did use it as the excuse for issuring the Emancipation Proclamation.

reviewText: Lincoln and Lee at Antietam covers the entire struggle of the Antietam Campaign.  The political concept about why Lincoln needed a Union victory and Lee's need to take the war north were covered as well as the battle.  With various interviews featuring historians such as James McPherson, this documentary is very well done.  The battle coverage is brief and not entirely descriptive although it includes reenactment scenes from the 125th, 135th and 140th Antietam Reenactments.  A majority of the footage and photography is excellent as it shows the beauty of the Maryland landscape around Antietam. Some of the film really points out General McClellan's "slow-to-react" method of dealing with Lee's invasion and how he missed a multiple of opportunities to really whip Lee during this campaign.Being a reenactor, covering a battle in detail in under two hours is nearly impossible.  Naturally I would like to see more.  I did enjoy the political views shown on both sides be it Union or Confederate.  It showcased the importance of how crucial this conflict was to each party.  It presented the facts about what could be gained and lost for both armies and governments that I liked.For a veteran reenactor or student of the battle of Antietam, a majority of this presentation is fairly basic and might be too standard although McPherson's explanation about why Antietam was politically important for Lincoln is something most people could learn about in this great presentation.
Title: N/A
